No URL in ref., so access-date is unnecessary
revision.text:
There are a number of documented cases of historical figures and distinguished members of society who were '''kidney stone formers'''. This condition is caused by nephrolithiasis, which are more commonly known as [[kidney stone]]s, or urolithiasis, where the stone forms in the urinary system. These are crystal deposits that can accrete in the [[urinary system]] when certain [[chemical substance]]s become concentrated in the [[urine]].<ref name=chiras2007>{{cite book | first=Daniel D. | last=Chiras | year=2007 | title=Human Biology | publisher=Jones & Bartlett Publishers | isbn=0-7637-3843-3 }}</ref> Among the symptoms associated with nephrolithiasis are intense [[Renal colic|colicky pain]], [[nausea]], [[fever]], chills, and the reduction or blockage of urine flow.<ref name=bmj328>{{cite journal | last=Parmar | first=Malvinder S. | title=Kidney stones | journal=British Medical Journal | year=2004 | volume=328 | issue=7453 | pages=1420–1424 | doi=10.1136/bmj.328.7453.1420 | pmid=15191979 | pmc=421787 }}</ref> Historically, the condition of having a kidney or bladder stone was referred to as "the stone" or "the gravel".
In certain cases, kidney stone formation played a pivotal role in history. Most notably, some members of the royalty and military leaders became debilitated at important moments, such as [[Napoleon III of France]]<ref name=Kertzer/> during the [[Franco-Prussian War]] of 1870 and [[Athenian]] commander [[Nicias]] in the disastrous [[Sicilian Expedition]] of 415-413 BC.<ref name=hanson/> Despite this condition, artists such as [[Arthur Sullivan]]<ref name=sullivan/> and [[Michel de Montaigne]]<ref name=montaigne/> managed to produce historically distinguished works; providing an example of perseverance in the face of severe and chronic pain. The medical advances of the twentieth century have allowed patients to survive the condition, whereas in the past it may have proven debilitating or fatal (as shown by the examples below).<ref name=moran2006>{{cite conference | first=Michael E. | last=Moran | title=Famous Stone Patients and their Disease | booktitle=Conference Proceedings, 1st Annual International Urolithiasis Research Symposium | pages=412–416 | publisher=American Institute of Physics | date=November 2–3, 2006 | location=Indianapolis, Indiana | bibcode=2007AIPC..900..412M | doi=10.1063/1.2723607}}</ref>
Kidney stones can reach exceptional size. In December 2003, a kidney stone weighing 356 g (12.5 oz) was removed from the right kidney of Peter Baulman of Australia. At its widest point, the stone measured 11.86 cm (4.66 in).<ref>{{cite web | author=Staff | year=2008 | url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records/human_body/medical_marvels/heaviest_kidney_stone.aspx | title=Heaviest Kidney Stone | publisher=Guinness World Records | accessdate=2008-05-25 }}</ref> In 2017, a 2 kg (4.4 lb) stone spanning 20 cm was surgically removed from Abdul Abu Al Hajjar in Kensington, England. As of August 2006, the most kidney stones ever passed naturally was 5,704 by Canadian Donald Winfield. The largest number removed through surgery was 728, during a three-hour operation upon Mangilal Jain of India, on January 27, 2004.<ref>{{cite book | first=Craig | last=Glenday | year=2008 | title=Guinness World Records 2008 | page=110 | publisher=Random House, Inc. | isbn=0-553-58995-4 }}</ref>
==Actors and media figures== * In 1954, movie actress [[Ava Gardner]] was hospitalized in [[Madrid]] with kidney stones. In her torment, she apparently yelled curses that caused the Spanish nuns to blush.<ref>{{cite book | first=Lee | last=Server | year=2007 | title=Ava Gardner: Love Is Nothing | publisher=Macmillan | isbn=0-312-31210-5 }}</ref>
* During the shooting of the film ''[[Family Plot]]'', [[Alfred Hitchcock]] underwent surgery for [[colitis]] and a kidney stone. He was also fitted with a [[pacemaker]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Charlotte | last=Chandler | year=2006 | title=It's Only a Movie: Alfred Hitchcock: A Personal | publisher=Hal Leonard | isbn=1-55783-692-2 }}</ref> * [[Hollywood]] [[talent agent]] [[Lew Wasserman]] was suffering from a kidney stone during the 1970s. As he was about to embark on an oceanic voyage, he insisted that it be surgically removed despite the risk and the reluctance of his doctor.<ref>{{cite book | first=Dennis | last=McDougal | year=2001 | title=The Last Mogul: Lew Wasserman, MCA, and the Hidden History of Hollywood | publisher=Da Capo Press | isbn=0-306-81050-6 }}</ref> * Early in the filming of ''[[Live and Let Die (film)|Live and Let Die]]'' (1973), actor [[Roger Moore]] was hospitalized from a pre-existing kidney stone condition.<ref>{{cite book | first=Alan | last=Barnes |author2=Hearn, Marcus | title=Kiss Kiss Bang! Bang!: The Unofficial James Bond 007 Film Companion | year=2003 | publisher=Sterling Publishing Company, Inc. | isbn=0-7134-8645-7 }}</ref> * During the shooting of the ''[[City Heat]]'' (1984), actor [[Burt Reynolds]] became debilitated from a kidney stone, and had to resort to medications to continue filming. He also suffered a broken jaw when struck by a metal chair and displayed inner ear problems.<ref>{{cite book | first=Patrick | last=McGilligan | year=2002 | title=Clint: The Life and Legend | publisher=Macmillan | isbn=0-312-29032-2 }}</ref> * Commentator [[Bill O'Reilly (commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] dislikes doctors, and so for two years he avoided medical attention for a kidney stone. It was surgically removed in 2002 and he was back on the air within four hours.<ref>{{cite book | first=Marvin | last=Kitman | year=2007 | title=The man who would not shut up: the rise of Bill O'Reilly | publisher=Macmillan | isbn=0-312-31435-3 }}</ref> * On October 19, 2005, while working on the set of ''[[Boston Legal]]'', actor [[William Shatner]] was taken to the emergency room for lower back pain. He eventually passed a kidney stone, but recovered and soon returned to work. Shatner sold his kidney stone in 2006 for $75,000 to [[GoldenPalace.com]]. The money went to a housing charity, and a home was built for a family which had lost theirs in [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Shatner |first=William |date=2006-01-20 |url=http://www.williamshatner.com/Article188.phtml |title=Getting Stoned |publisher=WilliamShatner.com |accessdate=2008-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312014317/http://www.williamshatner.com/Article188.phtml |archivedate=2007-03-12 |df= }}</ref> * While writing his book ''A Year at the Movies'', former ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'' cast member [[Kevin Murphy (actor)|Kevin Murphy]] (Tom Servo) passed a kidney stone, an experience he documented. * English [[radio producer]] [[Karl Pilkington]] was diagnosed with kidney stones in late August 2006.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2006-09-17 | title=The Idiot Philosopher | publisher=The Telegraph | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2006/09/17/svpilkington17.xml&page=10 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421093443/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2006/09/17/svpilkington17.xml&page=10 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2013-04-21 | accessdate=2008-05-29 }}</ref> * [[Buzz Kilman]], Chicago radio personality, took leave from the [[Steve Dahl]] show while on-air (announcing, "I gotta go") in order to have his kidney stone treated.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dahl |first=Steve |date=2007-09-14 |url=http://www.dahl.com/show_logs/2007/09/14.asp |title=Show Logs |publisher=JACK FM, Steve Dahl Show |accessdate=2008-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513044330/http://www.dahl.com/show_logs/2007/09/14.asp |archivedate=May 13, 2008 }}</ref> * Other actors and media figures who have suffered through a kidney stone include [[Tim Burton]],<ref>{{cite news | title=Tim Burton 'hospitalised in December' | first1=Mike | last1=Moody | date=January 10, 2011 | work=Digital Spy | publisher=Hearst Magazines UK | url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/news/a297088/tim-burton-hospitalised-in-december/ | accessdate=2016-12-02 }}</ref> [[Jamie Kennedy]],<ref>{{cite news | first=Howard | last=Breuer | date=March 30, 2009 | work=People Magazine | title=Jamie Kennedy 'On the Mend' with Jennifer Love Hewitt by His Side | url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20268754,00.html | accessdate=2010-04-05 }}</ref> [[Rob Schneider]],<ref>{{cite news |author=Staff |date=2003-05-23 |title=Rob Schneider: It's not easy being a slob |publisher=The Independent |url=http://www.menshealth.com/cda/article.do?site=MensHealth&channel=guy.wisdom&category=life.lessons&conitem=8fa1179799df6110VgnVCM10000013281eac____&page=2 |accessdate=2008-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624143442/http://www.menshealth.com/cda/article.do?site=MensHealth&channel=guy.wisdom&category=life.lessons&conitem=8fa1179799df6110VgnVCM10000013281eac____&page=2 |archivedate=2008-06-24 |df= }}</ref> [[Kiefer Sutherland]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Seal |first=Mark |year=2005 |url=http://www.americanwaymag.com/aw/travel/celebrated.asp?archive_date=12/15/2003 |title=Celebrated Weekend: 24 Hours in Toronto with Kiefer Sutherland |publisher=American Airlines, Inc |accessdate=2008-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023183547/http://americanwaymag.com/aw/travel/celebrated.asp?archive_date=12%2F15%2F2003 |archivedate=2007-10-23 |df= }}</ref> and [[Mike Vogel]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Staff |date=February 2008 |title=Burn Fat, Not Time |publisher=Men's Health |url=http://www.menshealth.com/cda/article.do?site=MensHealth&channel=guy.wisdom&category=life.lessons&conitem=8fa1179799df6110VgnVCM10000013281eac____&page=2 |accessdate=2008-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624143442/http://www.menshealth.com/cda/article.do?site=MensHealth&channel=guy.wisdom&category=life.lessons&conitem=8fa1179799df6110VgnVCM10000013281eac____&page=2 |archivedate=2008-06-24 |df= }}</ref>
==Artists and musicians== [[File:Sir_Arthur_Seymour_Sullivan.jpg|right|thumb|Arthur Sullivan wrote the comic opera ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'' in between bouts of excruciating pain from his kidney stones.<ref name=sullivan>{{cite book | first=Arthur | last=Sullivan |author2=Schwenck, William |author3=Gilbert, Ian Bradley | year=1996 | title=The Complete Annotated Gilbert and Sullivan | pages=115–116 | publisher=Oxford University Press | isbn=0-19-816710-5 }}</ref>]]
* In 1549, [[Italian Renaissance]] painter [[Michelangelo]] was treated for kidney stones by anatomist [[Realdo Colombo]]. Michelangelo appears to have suffered for many years from recurrent uric acid stones and may have died from obstructive [[nephropathy]]. His condition may account for his artistic interest in kidneys.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Eknoyan | first=Garabed | title=Michelangelo: Art, anatomy, and the kidney | journal=Kidney International | year=2000 | volume=57 | pages=1190–1201 | doi=10.1046/j.1523-1755.2000.00947.x | pmid=10720972 | issue=3 }}</ref> * Five years after retiring because of ill-health, in 1612 Italian composer [[Giovanni Gabrieli]] died from an attack of kidney stones.<ref>{{cite book | first=David Mason | last=Greene | year=1985 | title=Greene's biographical encyclopedia of Composers | publisher=Reproducing Piano Roll Fnd. | isbn=0-385-14278-1 }}</ref> * [[Arthur Sullivan]], of the musical partnership [[Gilbert and Sullivan]], began to suffer from kidney stones in 1872. This would affect him for the remainder of his life, although he would continue to write while suffering from pain. He underwent surgery in 1874 in an attempt to treat the condition.<ref>{{cite book | first=Isaac | last=Goldberg | year=1928 | title=The Story of Gilbert and Sullivan; Or, The 'Compleat' Savoyard | publisher=John Murray | location=London }}</ref> * Crooner [[Bing Crosby]] suffered from recurring kidney stones from 1951 onward, according to biographer [[George Carpozi, Jr.]].<ref>{{cite book | first=George | last=Carpozi | year=1977 | title=The Fabulous Life of Bing Crosby | publisher=Manor Books | isbn=0-532-19171-4 }}</ref> * Among his many medical maladies, in 1964 composer [[Cole Porter]] was hospitalized for the removal of kidney stones. He died two days later, most likely [[bronchopneumonia]] in his chest. He was also found to have chronic [[nephrosclerosis]], or degeneration of the kidneys.<ref>{{cite book | first=Charles | last=Schwartz | year=1979 | title=Cole Porter: a biography | publisher=Da Capo Press | isbn=0-306-80097-7 }}</ref> * Opera singer [[Birgit Nilsson]] painfully passed a kidney stone following a concert in [[Gothenburg|Göteborg, Sweden]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Birgit | last=Nilsson |author2=Popper, Doris Jung |author3=Tueller, Peggy | title=La Nilsson: My Life in Opera | year=2007 | publisher=UPNE | isbn=1-55553-670-0 }}</ref> * [[Tony Award|Tony-award]] winning composer [[Charles Strouse]] became infected as a result of a kidney stone. He recovered after treatment with antibiotics and the removal of the stone.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kenneth |last=Jones |date=June 1, 2010 |title=With a Song in His Heart, Charles Strouse Bounces Back After Illness |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/139983-With-a-Song-in-His-Heart-Charles-Strouse-Bounces-Back-After-Illness |accessdate=2010-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603140014/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/139983-With-a-Song-in-His-Heart-Charles-Strouse-Bounces-Back-After-Illness |archivedate=June 3, 2010 |df= }}</ref> * Chart singer [[Peter Andre]] was forced to postpone two shows at Plymouth Pavilions in 2010 because of a kidney stone.<ref>{{cite news | first=Peter | last=Andre | date=December 1, 2010 | title=Peter Andre gets the all clear | url=http://celebrity.uk.msn.com/news/gossip/articles.aspx?cp-documentid=155404956&pgnew=true&_p=57b0783d-787c-46bf-8fb1-1926fc3dd5f0&_nwpt=1#uc2Lst57b0783d-787c-46bf-8fb1-1926fc3dd5f0 | accessdate=2010-12-01 }}</ref> * Other artists and musicians who have suffered from a kidney stone include [[Nick Drake]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Orzeck |first=Kurt |date=2001-01-23 |title=Nick Drake |publisher=Virgin Mega Magazine |url=http://www.virginmegamagazine.com/default.asp?aid=2CD |accessdate=2008-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027000013/http://www.virginmegamagazine.com/default.asp?aid=2CD |archivedate=2007-10-27 |df= }}</ref> [[Billy Joel]],<ref>{{cite web |author=Columbia Records |url=http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/joel_billy/artist.jhtml |title=Billy Joel |publisher=MTV |accessdate=2008-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091227085849/http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/joel_billy/artist.jhtml |archivedate=2009-12-27 |df= }}</ref> [[Gene Simmons]],<ref>{{cite news | title=Kiss Kidney stone on eBay from Gene Simmons | date=June 6, 2009 | website=The Daily Telegraph | url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/weird/kiss-kidney-stone-on-ebay-from-gene-simmons/story-e6frev20-1225723384805 | accessdate=2016-12-02 }}</ref> and [[Owl City|Adam Young]].<ref name=dao20100806>{{cite news | title=Owl City calls in sick Saturday | date=August 6, 2010 | work=Democrat and Chronicle | publisher=August 6, 2010 | url=http://rocnow.com/article/local-news/20108060330 | accessdate=2010-08-09 }}</ref>
==Authors== [[File:Michel de Montaigne 1.jpg|right|thumb|Michel de Montaigne wrote of his condition that, "I am at grips with the worst of all maladies, the most sudden, the most painful, the most mortal and the most irremediable. I have already experienced five or six very long and painful bouts of it."<ref name=montaigne/>]]
* The [[post-mortem]] examination of noted diarist [[Samuel Pepys]] revealed, "a nest of no less than seven stones" in his left kidney. These weighed a total of 4.5 ounces. When he was younger, Pepys had undergone bladder surgery, pre-anesthesia, for removal of a large stone. He carried this stone with him to try to persuade fellow sufferers to endure the painful surgery.<ref>{{cite book | first=Samuel | last=Pepys |author2=Smith, John A. |author3=Smith, George G. | year=1905 | title=Diary of Samuel Pepys | publisher=Macmillan }}</ref> * [[Michel de Montaigne]], the French Renaissance writer who popularized the [[essay]], began to suffer from chronic kidney stones in 1578. His father had died from kidney stones.<ref name=montaigne>{{cite book | first=Michel | last=de Montaigne |author2=Frame, Donald M. | year=1958 | title=The complete essays of Montaigne | publisher=Stanford University Press | isbn=0-8047-0486-4 }}</ref> * Mary Ann Evans wrote under the male pen name of [[George Eliot]]. She had suffered from various health problems for all of her life, and starting in February 1874 she endured a series of kidney stone attacks that lasted until her death.<ref>{{cite book | first=Tim | last=Dolin | year=2005 | title=George Eliot | publisher=Oxford University Press | isbn=0-19-284047-9 }}</ref> * While visiting Italy, the author [[Llewelyn Powys]] began coughing up blood because of his [[tuberculosis]] and also suffered from a kidney stone. After he returned home to [[Dorset]], he passed the stone with excruciating pain. He had to take medication for the remainder of his life to avoid forming another stone.<ref>{{cite book | first=Richard Perceval | last=Graves | year=2002 | title=The Brothers Powys | publisher=Routledge | isbn=0-7100-9323-3 }}</ref> * American author [[Jack London]] used morphine to alleviate the pain of kidney stones. He most likely died<!-- 1916 --> at the age of forty from kidney failure and possibly a toxic dose of pain reliever.<ref>{{cite book | first=Dale L. | last=Walker | year=2006 | title=The Calamity Papers: Western Myths and Cold Cases | publisher=Macmillan | isbn=0-7653-0832-0 }}</ref> * At the end of her life in 1980, author [[Ethel Wilson]] was hospitalized and suffering from recurrent small [[stroke]]s. The day before she died, she was in physical distress from passing a kidney stone. A doctor injected her with medication to ease the pain.<ref>{{cite book | first=David | last=Stouck | year=2003 | title=Ethel Wilson: A Critical Biography | publisher=University of Toronto Press | isbn=0-8020-8741-8 }}</ref> * Author [[Isaac Asimov]] suffered from kidney stones, and wrote about how his pain was treated with [[morphine]], saying that he feared becoming [[Substance dependence|addicted]] to morphine if he ever needed it again.<ref>{{cite book | first=Isaac | last=Asimov | year=1995 | title=I. Asimov: A Memoir | publisher=Bantam | isbn=0-553-56997-X }}</ref> During the 1980s, his problem with kidney stones developed into kidney disease, which resulted in multiple hospitalizations.<ref>{{cite book |title= Isaac Asimov: A Life of the Grand Master of Science Fiction |last1= White |first1= Michael C. |authorlink1= |editor1-last= |editor1-first= | editor1-link= |date= 2005 |publisher= Carroll & Graf Publishers |location= |isbn= 0786715189 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EWbMiyS9v98C}}</ref> * In his book ''A Year at the Movies'', ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'' writer and performer [[Kevin Murphy (actor)|Kevin Murphy]] describes his ordeal with a kidney stone: "Being gut-stabbed with a dirty spoon in a prison cafeteria is less painful."<ref>{{cite book | first=Kevin | last=Murphy | year=2002 | title=A Year at the Movies: One Man's Filmgoing Odyssey | publisher=Harper Paperbacks | isbn=0-06-093786-6 }} </ref><ref>{{cite news |last = Stanley |first = Jonathan |date = 2002-09-27 |title = Kevin Murphy talks about movies, life, 'fanboys' |publisher = The Herald of Arkansas State University |url = http://media.www.asuherald.com/media/storage/paper898/news/2002/09/27/Features/Kevin.Murphy.Talks.About.Movies.Life.fanboys-1766027.shtml |accessdate = 2008-05-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20110707183715/http://media.www.asuherald.com/media/storage/paper898/news/2002/09/27/Features/Kevin.Murphy.Talks.About.Movies.Life.fanboys-1766027.shtml |archivedate = 2011-07-07 |df = }}</ref> * [[Chuck Palahniuk]], the author of ''[[Fight Club (novel)|Fight Club]]'', wrote about his experience with passing a kidney stone in his nonfiction book ''[[Stranger Than Fiction: True Stories]]''.<ref>{{cite book | first=Chuck | last=Palahniuk | year=2005 | title=Stranger Than Fiction: True Stories | publisher=Anchor | isbn=0-385-72222-2 }}</ref> * ''[[Washington Post]]'' columnist and [[Pulitzer Prize]] winner [[Art Buchwald]] suffered from a kidney stone late in his life.<ref>{{cite book | first=Art | last=Buchwald | year=2006 | title=Too Soon to Say Goodbye | publisher=Random House | isbn=1-4000-6627-1 }}</ref> * During a book tour, best selling author [[David Sedaris]] started passing a kidney stone. He completed several lectures while on pain medication.<ref>{{cite news | first=Joe | last=Brown | date=May 1, 2009 | title=Family fun makes best-seller | publisher=Las Vegas Sun | url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/may/01/family-fun-makes-best-seller/ | accessdate=2009-05-18 }}</ref>
==Nobility and emperors==
* Caesar [[Augustus]], the first [[Roman Emperor|emperor]] of the [[Roman Empire]], suffered from various physical maladies including kidney and bladder stones.<ref>{{cite book | first=Richard A. | last=Gabriel | year=2000 | pages=194 | title=Great Captains of Antiquity | publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group | isbn=0-313-31285-0 }}</ref> * From at least 1518, [[Frederick III, Elector of Saxony]] suffered from [[gout]] and kidney stones.<ref>{{cite book | first=Thomas Brian | last=Deutscher | year=2003 | title=Contemporaries of Erasmus: A Biographical Register of the Renaissance and Reformation | publisher=University of Toronto Press | isbn=0-8020-8577-6 }}</ref> * [[James I of England]] suffered from several symptoms characteristic of kidney stones, including abdominal colic and passing red urine. Following his death in 1625, stones were found in his kidney.<ref>{{cite book | first=Geoffrey | last=Dean | year=2005 | title=The Turnstone: A Doctor's Story | publisher=Liverpool University Press | isbn=0-85323-757-3 }}</ref> * While he was alive, King [[Louis XIV of France]] frequently voided kidney stones but without suffering apparent pain. A small stone was found in the left kidney of his corpse.<ref>{{cite book | first=Henry | last=Dupey | editor=Johnson, James | title=The Medico-chirurgical Review, Volume Twelve | chapter=XLVII. Post-Mortem Examinations of the Kings of France | publisher=Richard & George S. Wood | year=1830 | location=New York | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LhqaSmGih8QC | accessdate=2008-06-05 }}</ref> * In 1722 the Russian ruler [[Peter the Great]] began to experience kidney problems. The symptoms grew worse during 1723 and by the following year it was diagnosed as the stone. He suffered from extreme pain in the loins and then tumors began to form on his thighs. Early in 1725 he died.<ref>{{cite book | first=Kazimierz | last=Waliszewski | others=Translated by Lady Mary Loyd | year=1897 | title=Peter the Great | publisher=William Heinemann | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_aE2AAAAMAAJ | accessdate=2008-05-30 | location=London }}</ref> * Empress [[Anna of Russia]] was known to suffer from kidney stones, and in 1740 her condition became more acute. After becoming bedridden, she died later the same year. An autopsy showed that the stones resembled branching coral.<ref>{{cite book | first=Evgeniĭ Viktorovich | last=Anisimov |author2=Carroll, Kathleen | year=2004 | title=Five Empresses: Court Life in Eighteenth-Century Russia | pages=124 | publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group | isbn=0-275-98464-8 }}</ref> * After his death,<!-- 1830 --> English [[George IV of the United Kingdom|King George IV]] was found to have a bladder stone that had become encysted.<ref>{{cite journal | last=John | first=Adams | title=Lithotomy in Children | journal=The London Lancet: A Journal of British and Foreign Medical, Surgical and Chemical Science | year=1858 | volume=1 | pages=275–277 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=swwCAAAAYAAJ | accessdate=2008-06-11 | publisher=Burgess, Stringer & Co. }}</ref> A year before his death he had complained of a pain in his bladder.<ref>{{cite book | first=Saul | last=David | year=2000 | title=Prince of Pleasure: The Prince of Wales and the | publisher=Grove Press | isbn=0-8021-3703-2 }}</ref> * With his health deteriorating, in 1860 [[Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald|Lord Cochrane]] twice underwent surgery for kidney stones. He died during the second operation.<ref>{{cite book | first=Brian | last=Vale | year=2008 | title=Cochrane in the Pacific: Fortune and Freedom in Spanish America | publisher=I. B. Tauris | isbn=1-84511-446-9 }}</ref> * King [[Leopold I of Belgium]] underwent a lithotrity in 1862 for the removal of a kidney stone. However, the operation was only partly successful and he underwent a second surgery in 1863. For the latter operation, [[Sir Henry Thompson, 1st Baronet|Sir Henry Thompson]] was appointed surgeon-extraordinary to the King.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Staff | title=Obituary: Sir Henry Thompson | journal=Medical Press and Circular | year=1904 | volume=77 | pages=463 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UxoCAAAAYAAJ | accessdate=2008-06-28 }}</ref> * [[Napoleon I of France]] became ill with a kidney stone during the [[Battle of Borodino]], September 7, 1812. This condition may help explain his unoriginal tactics during the battle.<ref>{{cite book | first=Steven | last=Englund | year=2004 | title=Napoleon: A Political Life | publisher=Simon and Schuster | isbn=0-684-87142-4 }}</ref> * Dom [[Pedro I of Brazil]] suffered from frequent kidney stone attacks.<ref>{{cite book | first=Neill | last=Macaulay | year=1986 | title=Dom Pedro: The Struggle for Liberty in Brazil | publisher=Duke University Press | isbn=0-8223-0681-6 }}</ref> * [[Napoleon III of France]] may have lost the [[Franco-Prussian war]] of 1870 in part because of a massive kidney stone. He died from kidney stone surgery in 1873.<ref name=Kertzer>{{cite book | first=David I. | last=Kertzer | year=2004 | title=Prisoner of the Vatican: The Popes' Secret Plot | publisher=Houghton Mifflin Books | isbn=0-618-22442-4 }}</ref> * [[Māori people|Māori]] Queen Dame [[Te Atairangikaahu]] was hospitalized for kidney surgery in 2005, a few weeks after the 40th anniversary of her coronation.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2006-08-16 | title=Dame Te Ata, 75, Maori Queen and Promoter of Their Culture, Dies | website=The New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/16/world/asia/16ata.html?_r=1 | accessdate=2008-06-15 }}</ref>
==Politicians and military commanders==
* In the disastrous [[Sicilian Expedition]] (415-413 BC), the Athenian commander [[Nicias]] was afflicted with kidney stones during the entire period he was in charge.<ref name=hanson>{{cite book | first=Victor Davis | last=Hanson |author2=Keegan, John | year=2000 | title=The Western Way of War: Infantry Battle in | publisher=University of California Press | isbn=0-520-21911-2 }}</ref> * The English military and political leader [[Oliver Cromwell]] may have suffered from kidney stones during the 1650s. His doctor said that, "being much troubled with the stone, he used sometimes to swill down several sorts of liquor, and then stir his body by some violent motion ... that by such agitation he might disburden his bladder."<ref>{{cite book | first=H. F. | last=McMains | year=2000 | title=The Death of Oliver Cromwell | publisher=University Press of Kentucky | isbn=0-8131-2133-7 }}</ref> *In 1659, [[Myles Standish]], who served as military officer of the [[Pilgrims]] at [[Plymouth Colony]], became "sick of the stone" and died after suffering much "dolorous pain".<ref>{{cite book | first=Thomas Cruddas | last=Porteus | year=1920 | title=Captain Myles Standish: His Lost Lands and Lancashire Connections | chapter=Chapter I. The Character and Career of Captain Standish | publisher=Longmans, Green & Co. | location=Manchester }}</ref> * Sir [[Robert Walpole]], generally regarded as the first [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister of Great Britain]], suffered from the stone, as did his brother [[Horace Walpole, 4th Earl of Orford|Horace Walpole]] and his mother [[Catherine, Lady Walpole|Catherine]].<ref>{{cite journal | last=Flynn | first=J. | title=Heredity and Disease | journal=Australasian Medical Gazette | year=1901 | volume=20 | pages=225–238 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HJ1XAAAAMAAJ | accessdate=2008-06-11 | publisher=L. Bruck }}</ref> * [[John Hart (New Jersey politician)|John Hart]], a member of the [[Continental Congress]] representing [[New Jersey]] and signer of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]], died of kidney stones in 1779 after much suffering.<ref>{{cite web |last=Staller |first=Grace Keiper |url=http://www.dsdi1776.com/Signers/John%20Hart.html |title=John Hart, Delaware, (1713–1779) |publisher=Descendents of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence |accessdate=2008-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204025336/http://www.dsdi1776.com/Signers/John%20Hart.html |archivedate=2008-12-04 |df= }}</ref> * British General [[James Wolfe]] suffered from "the gravel" prior to the [[Battle of the Plains of Abraham|Battle of Quebec]] during the [[Seven Years' War]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Beckles | last=Willson |author2=Wolfe, James | year=1909 | title=The Life and Letters of James Wolfe | publisher=William Heinemann | location=London }}</ref>
[[File:Polkpolk.jpg|right|thumb|The dangerous and painful surgery used to remove a stone through James K. Polk's [[perineum]] may have left him unable to conceive a child.<ref name=seigenthaler/>]] * The eleventh President of the United States, [[James K. Polk]], suffered from kidney stones during his youth. At the age of seventeen he underwent a successful [[lithotomy]] without [[anaesthetic]] for removal of a urinary stone. Thereafter he was sufficiently well to be able to receive a formal education.<ref name=seigenthaler>{{cite book | first=John | last=Seigenthaler | year=2002 | title=James K. Polk | publisher=Macmillan | isbn=0-8050-6942-9 }}</ref> * Colonel [[Edward M. House]] was the foreign policy advisor to President [[Woodrow Wilson]] until removed from that post in 1919. In that year he suffered through a painful kidney stone, and he had recurrences in 1928 and 1930.<ref>{{cite book | first=Godfrey | last=Hodgson | year=2006 | title=Woodrow Wilson's Right Hand: The Life of Colonel Edward M. House | publisher=Yale University Press | isbn=0-300-09269-5 }}</ref> * In 1959, Indian Prime Minister [[Indira Gandhi]] began to suffering from severe pain in the stomach and back. She was diagnosed with a kidney stone and underwent successful surgery in February 1960 to have it removed.<ref>{{cite book | first=Katherine | last=Frank | year=2002 | title=Indira: The Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi | publisher=Houghton Mifflin Books | isbn=0-395-73097-X }}</ref> * [[Sukarno]], the first President of [[Indonesia]], suffered from recurrent kidney stones. He was twice forced to seek medical treatment in [[Vienna]]; the second time for removal of a kidney stone.<ref>{{cite book | first=Angus | last=McIntyre | year=2005 | title=The Indonesian Presidency: The Shift From Personal toward Constitutional Rule | publisher=Rowman & Littlefield | isbn=0-7425-3827-3 }}</ref> * U.S. President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] suffered from kidney stones at various times in his life. He was reluctant to seek treatment because of the effect it may have on his political image.<ref>{{cite book | first=Robert E. | last=Gilbert | year=1998 | title=The Mortal Presidency: Illness and Anguish in the White House | publisher=Fordham Univ Press | isbn=0-8232-1837-6 }}</ref> * The perjury trial of [[Deputy White House Chief of Staff]] [[Michael Deaver]] was twice delayed because he was suffering from kidney stones.<ref>{{cite news | last=Franklin | first=Ben A. | date=1987-11-13 | title=Deaver's Illness Delays Trial | website=The New York Times | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEFDD1338F930A25752C1A961948260 | accessdate=2008-06-24 }}</ref> * Bosnian Serb military commander [[Ratko Mladić]] underwent surgery in Belgrade for a kidney stone in 1995, during the final year of the Serbian conflict with Bosnia.<ref>{{cite news | last=Perlez | first=Jane | date=1995-11-02 | title=Conflict in the Balkans: The Serbs; Banja Luka: Not a Target Of Assault, Yet Beaten | website=The New York Times | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9800E0DA1639F931A35752C1A963958260/ | accessdate=2008-06-24 }}</ref> He was later indicted by the UN War Crimes Tribunal for genocide and other crimes.<ref>{{cite news | last=Perlez | first=Jane | date=2005-06-06 | title=Profile: Ratko Mladic | publisher=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1423551.stm | accessdate=2008-06-24 }}</ref> * Former Speaker of the [[United States House of Representatives]], [[Dennis Hastert]], has had a number of kidney stones, necessitating kidney stone removal surgery.<ref>{{cite news |author=Staff |date=2001-04-03 |title=Hastert released after kidney stone surgery |publisher=CNN |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/ALLPOLITICS/04/03/hastert.health/index.html |accessdate=2008-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080221191219/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/ALLPOLITICS/04/03/hastert.health/index.html |archivedate=2008-02-21 |df= }}</ref> Senator [[John McCain]] has had four small kidney stones and he takes the [[diuretic]] [[hydrochlorothiazide]] to prevent their formation.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2008-05-03 | title=McCain in 'excellent health,' doctor says | url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/HEALTH/05/23/mccain.health.records/ | publisher=CNN | accessdate=2008-06-13 }}</ref> Other congress members who have experienced kidney stones include Representatives [[Tom Price (American politician)|Tom Price]] and [[Mike Simpson]],<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2005-04-13 | title=Kidney stone alert | publisher=The Hill | url=http://thehill.com/old-capital-living/sen.-ensigns-damaged-hand-2005-04-13.html | accessdate=2008-05-28 | deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709003531/http://thehill.com/old-capital-living/sen.-ensigns-damaged-hand-2005-04-13.html | archivedate=July 9, 2008 }}</ref> and Senator [[Ted Kennedy]].<ref> {{cite news | last = Nagourney | first = Adam | title = Determined to Give Speech, Kennedy Left Hospital Bed | website = The New York Times | date = 2008-08-26 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/27/us/politics/27kennedy.html?em | accessdate = 2008-08-26}} </ref> * Former White House Deputy Chief of Staff [[Karl Rove]] under U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] was hospitalized in September 2005 due to kidney stones.<ref>{{cite news | last=Allen | first=Mike | date= 2008-08-29 | title=Living Too Much in the Bubble? | publisher=Time Magazine | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1103581,00.html | accessdate=2008-08-29 }}</ref> * Former [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[John Prescott]] was hospitalized on [[Christmas Day]], 2006 for a kidney stone.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2007-06-04 | title=Prescott undergoes tests in hospital | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2007/jun/04/labourdeputy.labour1 | accessdate=2008-06-13 }}</ref> *Senior CIA lawyer [[John Rizzo]] had a number of kidney stone attacks, beginning in 1968.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Rizzo |first1=John |title=Company Man: Thirty Years of Controversy and Crisis in the CIA |date=2014 |publisher=Scribner |location=New York |isbn=978-1-4516-7393-7 |page=37}}</ref> * Other political figures who have had a kidney stone include U.S. Treasury Secretary [[Timothy Geithner]]<ref>{{cite news | first1=Martin | last1=Crutsinger | title=Geithner to have surgery for kidney stones | work=Seattle Times | date=December 10, 2010 | url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/geithner-to-have-surgery-for-kidney-stones/ | accessdate=2016-12-02 }}</ref> and British Labour politician [[Peter Mandelson]].<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2008-10-07 | title=Kidney op Mandelson back at work | publisher=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7654252.stm | accessdate=2008-10-07 }}</ref>
==Religious figures==
* [[Pope Vigilius]], whose papacy began in 537, died in [[Sicily]] while suffering from kidney stones, 555.<ref>{{cite book | first=James Allan | last=Evans | year=2005 | title=The Emperor Justinian and the Byzantine Empire | publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group | isbn=0-313-32582-0 }}</ref> * Saint [[Ailred of Rievaulx]] took frequent baths and consumed wine to alleviate the severe pain from his kidney stones.<ref>{{cite book | first=Thomas J. | last=Heffernan | year=1988 | title=Sacred Biography: Saints and Their Biographers | publisher=Oxford University Press US | isbn=0-19-507907-8 }}</ref> * The German monk [[Martin Luther]] periodically suffered from kidney stones, and he almost died in 1537 from being unable to urinate. During his lengthy journey home, the jostling motion of the carriage released the stone and so spared his life.<ref>{{cite book | first=Eric W. | last=Gritsch | year=2006 | title=The Wit of Martin Luther | publisher=Fortress Press | isbn=0-8006-3803-4 }}</ref> * During his life,<!-- to 1564 --> the French [[Protestant]] [[John Calvin]] would suffer from a variety of physical ailments, including kidney stones, [[arthritis]], a bleeding stomach, gout and [[nephritis]].<ref>{{cite book | first=William J. | last=Bouwsma | year=1988 | title=John Calvin: A Sixteenth-century Portrait | publisher=Oxford University Press US | isbn=0-19-505951-4 }}</ref> * [[Cardinal Mazarin]], the successor to [[Cardinal Richelieu]] as the French King's Chief Minister, began to suffer from kidney stones in 1659. He died two years later while also suffering from gout and deteriorating health.<ref>{{cite book | first=Anthony | last=Levi | year=2004 | title=Louis XIV | publisher=Carroll & Graf Publishers | isbn=0-7867-1309-7 }}</ref>
[[File:John Wilkins.jpg|right|thumb|To treat his kidney stones, John Wilkins was fed, "four red-hot [[oyster]] shells in a quart of [[cider]] and blistering with [[Spanish fly|cantharides]]."<ref name=inwood/>]] * After surviving the plague year of 1665, English clergyman, author and chief founder of the [[Royal Society]] [[John Wilkins]] became ill from kidney stones and he was unable to pass urine. He most likely died<!-- 1672 --> from the opiates or other medications that were used to treat his condition.<ref name=inwood>{{cite book | first=Stephen | last=Inwood | year=2005 | title=The Forgotten Genius: The Biography of Robert Hooke 1635–1703 | publisher=MacAdam/Cage Publishing | isbn=1-59692-115-3 }}</ref> * [[Pope Innocent XI]] survived primitive surgery for the extraction of kidney stones.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Carrieri | first=Maria Patrizia |author2=Serraino, Diego | title=Longevity of popes and artists between the 13th and the 19th century | journal=International Journal of Epidemiology | year=2005 | volume=34 | issue=6 | pages=1435–1436 | doi=10.1093/ije/dyi211 | pmid=16260451 }}</ref> After his death in 1689, he was found to have a "stone weighing nine ounces in the left kidney and another weighing six ounces in the right side."<ref name=debout>{{cite book | first=Albert Émile | last=Debout | year=1883 | title=Medical guide to Contrexéville | pages=96–119 | publisher=J. & A. Churchill | location=London | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IxgDAAAAQAAJ | isbn=0-19-521833-7 }}</ref> * [[Mary Baker Eddy]] was the founder of [[Christian Science]], a movement that discouraged its members from seeking help from doctors for their illnesses. In 1903 she began to suffer from extreme pain and consented to a visit by a doctor. After a diagnosis of kidney stones, she agreed to injections of morphine to alleviate the pain.<ref>{{cite book | first=Stephen | last=Gottschalk | year=2005 | title=Rolling away the stone: Mary Baker Eddy's Challenge to Materialism | publisher=Indiana University Press | isbn=0-253-34673-8 }}</ref> * In 1954, when [[Billy Graham]] was preparing to preach at Berlin's [[Olympic Stadium (Berlin)|Olympic Stadium]], he began to suffer pain from a kidney stone. Wondering whether the [[Devil]] might be mounting a vengeful attack against him,<ref>{{cite book | first=Roger | last=Bruns | year=2004 | title=Billy Graham: A Biography | publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group | isbn=0-313-32718-1 }}</ref> he chose to continue the public service without painkillers, rather than appearing groggy or undergoing hospitalization.<ref>{{cite book | first=Billy | last=Graham | authorlink=Billy Graham | year=1999 | title=Just as I Am: The Autobiography of Billy Graham | publisher=HarperCollins | isbn=0-06-063392-1 }}</ref> * After praying to [[Mother Teresa]], a {{convert|1/2|in|mm|adj=mid|-diameter}} kidney stone disappeared from the lower ureter of Father V. M. Thomas in [[Guwahati]], India. This occurred a day before the priest was scheduled to undergo surgery for the stone's removal. The surgeon said that, "the disappearance of the calculus (stone) was beyond medical explanation." This alleged miracle was used to support the case for [[saint]]hood of Mother Teresa.<ref>{{cite news |author = Staff |date = 2007-10-01 |title = Indian priest says his cure was miracle through Mother Teresa |publisher = Catholic news Service |url = http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0705561.htm |archive-url = http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20071009164449/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0705561.htm |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2007-10-09 |accessdate = 2008-05-29 }}</ref> * In 2010, [[David Zubik]], bishop of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh]], was hospitalized with kidney stones.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bishop Zubik Hospitalized With Kidney Stones |date=Apr 2, 2010 |publisher=KDKA, CBS Broadcasting Inc. |url=http://kdka.com/local/bishop.zubik.hospitalized.2.1607970.html |accessdate=2010-05-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409082917/http://kdka.com/local/bishop.zubik.hospitalized.2.1607970.html |archivedate=2010-04-09 |df= }}</ref>
==Scholars, scientists and philosophers== [[File:Thomas Sydenham.jpg|right|thumb|Thomas Sydenham began to suffer from kidney stones at the age of 25.<ref name=Sydenham/>]]
* In 271 or 270 BC, the Greek Philosopher [[Epicurus]] died from a stone blockage of his urinary tract lasting a fortnight, according to his successor [[Hermarchus]] and reported by his biographer [[Diogenes Laertius]].<ref>{{cite journal | last=Bitsori | first=Maria |author2=Galanakis, Emmanouil | title=Epicurus’ death | journal=World Journal of Urology | year=2004 | volume=22 | issue=6 | pages=466–469 | doi=10.1007/s00345-004-0448-2 | pmid=15372192 }}</ref> * The [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Renaissance humanism|humanist]] and [[theology|theologian]] [[Desiderius Erasmus]] suffered from gout, kidney stone and hypochondria.<ref>{{cite book | first=Roy | last=Porter | year=1999 | title=The Greatest Benefit to Mankind: A Medical History of Humanity | publisher=W. W. Norton & Company | isbn=0-393-31980-6 }}</ref> * In describing his kidney stones, the physician [[Thomas Sydenham]]<!-- b. 1624 --> said, "The pain is like that of a dislocation and yet parts feel as if cold water had been poured over them... Now it is a gnawing pain and now it is a pressure and tightening. So exquisite and lively meanwhile is the feeling of the part affected, that it cannot bear the weight of the bedclothes nor the jar of a person walking in the room."<ref name=Sydenham>{{cite book | first=Walter | last=Gratzer | year=2005 | title=Terrors of the Table: The Curious History of Nutrition | publisher=Oxford University Press | isbn=0-19-280661-0 }}</ref> * [[Robert Boyle]],<!-- b. 1627 --> regarded as the first modern chemist, was troubled for much of his adult life by kidney stones.<ref>{{cite book | first=Marie Boas | last=Hall | year=1965 | title=Robert Boyle on Natural Philosophy: an Essay with Selections from his Writings | publisher=Indiana University Press }}</ref> * After retiring from the Lumleian lectureship at [[Cambridge University]] in 1655, the aging physician [[William Harvey]] was known to suffer from gout and kidney stones. He is noted for his correct description of blood and the circulatory system.<ref>{{cite book | first=John Galbraith | last=Simmons | year=2002 | title=Doctors and discoveries: lives that created | publisher=Houghton Mifflin Reference Books | isbn=0-618-15276-8 }}</ref> * In 1686, Danish anatomist and geologist [[Nicholas Steno]] became gravely ill from kidney stones. He suffered great pain and his stomach became distended. Shortly before he died, he prayed that, "My God I beg you not to take the pains from me, but to give me the patience to bear them."<ref>{{cite book | first=Karen | last=Ascani |author2=Kermit, Hans |author3=Skytte, Gunver | year=2002 | title=Niccolò Stenone (1638–1686): anatomista, geologo, vescovo | publisher=L'Erma di Bretschneider | isbn=88-8265-213-0 }}</ref> * [[Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon]], French naturalist, suffered from kidney stones in 1771 and their "passing caused him very sharp pains". He had 57 stones at time of autopsy in 1788.<ref>{{cite book | first=Jacques | last=Roger | others=translated by Sarah Lucille Bonnefoi | year=1997 | title=Buffon: A Life in Natural History | publisher=Cornell University Press | isbn=0-8014-2918-8 }}</ref> * During Sir [[Isaac Newton's later life]], he was troubled by painful urinary incontinence, probably due to uric acid stones in the bladder.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ostad |first=Edward |author2=Wise, Gilbert J. |title=Celestial bodies and urinary stones: Isaac Newton (1641–1727) – health and urological problems |journal=BJU International |year=2005 |volume=95 |issue=1 |pages=24–26 |url=http://www.urotoday.com/prod/pdf/reviews/BJU4_jan2005.pdf |accessdate=2008-05-22 |doi=10.1111/j.1464-410X.2005.05242.x |pmid=15638889 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111075612/http://www.urotoday.com/prod/pdf/reviews/BJU4_jan2005.pdf |archivedate=2006-11-11 |df= }}</ref> * The distinguished mathematician and philosopher [[Gottfried Leibniz]] died from a combination of gout and the stone. Although he was a member of several distinguished societies, he had fallen into such disfavor that only one man came to his funeral.<ref>{{cite book | first=John Theodore | last=Merz | year=1884 | title=Leibniz | publisher=William Blackwood and Sons | location=Edinburgh and London }}</ref> * In the final years of his life, [[Benjamin Franklin]] is known to have used [[laudanum]], an [[alcohol]]ic herbal preparation of [[opium]], to alleviate the pain of recurrent kidney stones.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Musto |first=David F. |title=Opium, Cocaine and Marijuana in American History |journal=Scientific American |date=July 1991 |pages=20–27 |url=http://www.drugtext.org/library/articles/musto01.htm |accessdate=2008-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080523211539/http://www.drugtext.org/library/articles/musto01.htm |archivedate=2008-05-23 |df= }}</ref> * The eminent Italian anatomist and surgeon [[Antonio Scarpa]] suffered severely from a stone for several years. This caused a bladder inflammation which led to his demise in 1832.<ref>{{cite book | author=Various | year=1841 | title=Penny cyclopaedia of the Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge, volume 21 | publisher=Charles Knight & Co. | location=London }}</ref>
==Sports figures== * Nearing the end of his life, in 1985 the father of competitive weightlifting, [[Bob Hoffman (weightlifter)|Bob Hoffman]], suffered from a number of physical ailments, including kidney stones.<ref>{{cite book | first=John D. | last=Fair | year=1999 | title=Muscletown USA: Bob Hoffman and the Manly Culture of York Barbell | publisher=Penn State Press | isbn=0-271-01855-0 }}</ref> * [[New York Giants]] football coach [[Bill Parcells]] underwent medical treatment for a kidney stone in 1990. Against his doctor's advice, Bill Parcels attempted to coach the next game against the [[Minnesota Vikings]], but a reporter noted he "appeared drawn and in pain".<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=1990-12-11 | title=Parcells Home After Treatment | website=The New York Times | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEFDE1E3EF932A25751C1A966958260 | accessdate=2008-06-15 }}</ref> * During a 1996 attempt to cross Antarctica, explorer and endurance record holder Sir [[Ranulph Fiennes]] was forced to turn back because of kidney stones. He lists it as his most painful experience.<ref>{{cite web|last=Patalay |first=Ajesh |date=2007-01-20 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/2007/01/20/smworld20.xml |title=The world of Sir Ranulph Fiennes |publisher=The Telegraph |accessdate=2008-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070122160458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=%2Farts%2F2007%2F01%2F20%2Fsmworld20.xml |archivedate=January 22, 2007 |df= }}</ref> * [[Los Angeles Lakers]] head coach [[Phil Jackson]] underwent a [[lithotripsy]] procedure to treat a kidney stone in 2003. It was the first time he missed a game as coach. He had experienced symptoms for two years prior to the surgery.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2003-02-25 | title=L. A. Lakers coach has kidney stone removed | publisher=Daily Vidette, Illinois State University | url=http://media.www.dailyvidette.com/media/storage/paper420/news/2003/02/25/Sports/L.a-Lakers.Coach.Has.Kidney.Stone.Removed-378180.shtml | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130408011532/http://media.www.dailyvidette.com/media/storage/paper420/news/2003/02/25/Sports/L.a-Lakers.Coach.Has.Kidney.Stone.Removed-378180.shtml | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2013-04-08 | accessdate=2008-05-31 }}</ref> * Professional [[golf]]er [[Davis Love III]] had to withdraw from the 2007 [[Wyndham Championship]] to undergo surgery for a kidney stone. Afterward he said that, "Except for feeling like I've been punched in the side, I feel fine."<ref>{{cite news | last=Jones | first=Brent | date=2007-08-17 | title=Davis Love III recovering after kidney stone surgery | publisher=The Associated Press/USA Today | url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/golf/pga/2007-08-17-love-surgery_N.htm | accessdate=2008-06-13 }}</ref> * [[Bernhard Langer]] had to pull out of the 2007 Deutsche Bank Players' Championship to undergo an operation for kidney stone removal.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2007-07-26 | title=Bernhard Langer pulls out of Deutsche Bank Players' Championship after kidney operation | publisher=International Herald Tribune | url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/07/26/sports/EU-SPT-GLF-Deutsche-Bank-Langer.php | accessdate=2008-06-29 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016}}</ref> * [[Blackpool F.C.]] boss [[Ian Holloway]] was taken to hospital in August 2007 with a kidney stone.<ref>{{cite news | author=BBC Sport | date=2007-08-18 | title=Boss Holloway rushed to hospital | publisher=BBC Sport | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/p/plymouth_argyle/6953017.stm | accessdate=2007-08-18 }}</ref> * [[Palmeiras]] coach [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] and [[Inter Milan]] manager [[Rafael Benítez]] both suffered from kidney stones in 2008.<ref>{{cite news | first1=Geoffrey | last1=Mills | date=2008-12-16 | title=Rafa Benitez and Luiz Felipe Scolari both have kidney stones | publisher=The Sun | url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/article2041750.ece | accessdate=2008-12-16 }}</ref> * In March 2009, driver [[Martin Truex, Jr.]] was hospitalized before the Atlanta's Cup race with a kidney stone. Because of the [[NASCAR]] drug regulations, he decided to forgo medications while passing the stone so that he could compete in the race.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff Writer | title=Earnhardt Ganassi Racing' Martin Truex Jr. respects NASCAR's drug policy | publisher=SceneDaily.com | date=May 15, 2009 | url=http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Earnhardt_Ganassi_Racing_Martin_Truex_Jr_respects_NASCARs_drug_policy.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223170459/http://www.scenedaily.com/news/articles/sprintcupseries/Earnhardt_Ganassi_Racing_Martin_Truex_Jr_respects_NASCARs_drug_policy.html|archivedate=February 23, 2012 | accessdate=2009-05-18 }}</ref> * During the 2009 [[National Hockey League]] playoffs, all-star right winger [[Mark Recchi]] underwent surgery to have a kidney stone removed. He said of the pain, "I don't wish it on anybody."<ref>{{cite news | first=Steve | last=Conroy | title=Mark Recchi leaves no stone unturned | publisher=Boston Herald | date=May 15, 2009 | url=http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/hockey/bruins/view.bg?articleid=1172451&srvc=sports&position=recent|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916211832/http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/hockey/bruins/view.bg?articleid=1172451&srvc=sports&position=recent|archivedate=September 16, 2012 }}</ref> * In December 2011, [[Marcus Thornton (basketball, born 1987)|Marcus Thornton]] of the Sacramento Kings suffered a kidney stone.<ref>{{cite web | title=Kings injury update: John Salmons right quad, Marcus Thornton kidney stone | work=Cowbell Kingdom | first1=Jonathan | last1=Santiago | date=December 22, 2011 | url=http://cowbellkingdom.com/kings-injury-update-john-salmons-right-quad-marcus-thornton-kidney-stone/ | accessdate=2016-07-13 }}</ref> * In November 2017, [[Vince Carter]] of the Sacramento Kings suffered a kidney stone<ref name=Nathan2017>{{citation | title=Vince Carter Ruled Out vs. 76ers with Kidney Stones | work=Bleacher Report | publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. | first=Alec | last1=Nathan | date=November 9, 2017 | url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2743487-vince-carter-ruled-out-vs-76ers-with-kidney-stones | accessdate=2017-11-13 | postscript=. }}</ref> * Winner of the 2003 [[Grand National]], Jockey [[Barry Geraghty]] was hospitalized with a kidney stone in 2015. He said, "I was in a lot of pain and had to have plenty of morphine."<ref>{{cite news | first1=Tony | last1=O'Hehir | date=July 1, 2015 | title=Geraghty set for return despite kidney stone | newspaper=Racing Post | url=http://www.racingpost.com/news/horse-racing/barry-geraghty-geraghty-set-for-weekend-return-despite-kidney-stone/1907888/#newsArchiveTabs=last7DaysNews | accessdate=2015-07-09 }}</ref> * At the age of 50, [[Olympic games|Olympic]] gold medalist [[Caitlyn Jenner]] (then Bruce){{efn|Jenner changed her name due to [[gender transition]] in 2015.<ref>{{cite web | last=Leibovitz | first=Annie | date=June 1, 2015 | title=Introducing Caitlyn Jenner | work=Vanity Fair | accessdate=June 1, 2015 | url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/06/caitlyn-jenner-bruce-cover-annie-leibovitz/ }}</ref>}} discovered that she had a kidney stone after undergoing a full body [[Electron beam tomography|EBCT]] scan.<ref>{{cite news | last=Morain | first=Claudia | date=2000-10-01 | title=New Tests See Right Through Potential Problems | website=San Francisco Chronicle | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2000/10/01/SPECIAL113537.DTL | accessdate=2008-06-27 }}</ref> * During 2016, [[FC Barcelona]] forward [[Lionel Messi]] apparently played three games with a stone in his kidney. He used tranquillizers during the games, then underwent a lithotripsy to break up the stone.<ref>{{cite news | first1=Nick | last1=Eilerson | date=March 11, 2016 | website=The Washington Post | title=Lionel Messi played three games with kidney stones, apparently | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2016/03/11/lionel-messi-played-three-games-with-kidney-stones-apparently/ | accessdate=2016-03-30 | postscript=. }}</ref> * Golfer [[Bubba Watson]] passed two kidney stones in five years.<ref>{{cite news | first1=Kyle | last1=Porter | date=February 22, 2016 | publisher=CBS Sports | title=Bubba Watson passed a kidney stone before Northern Trust Open win | url=http://www.cbssports.com/golf/eye-on-golf/25491387/bubba-watson-reveals-he-passed-a-kidney-stone-before-northern-trust-open-win | accessdate=2016-05-27 | postscript=. }}</ref>
===Baseball===
* [[Baseball Hall of Fame]]r [[Tony Gwynn]] had a kidney stone removed [[Arthroscopy|arthroscopically]] in 1997.<ref>{{cite web | author=Staff | date=1997-08-11 | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A04E0D7103CF932A2575BC0A961958260 | title=Kidney Stones Sideline Gwynn | website=The New York Times | accessdate=2008-06-15 }}</ref> * [[New York Mets]]' [[relief pitcher]] [[Dennis Cook]] began to suffer from a kidney stone just as his team reached the [[World Series]] in 2000. However, he was able to pitch during the first game.<ref>{{cite news | last=Rubin | first=Roger | author2=Garcia, Julian | title=On Computer, Yankees More than Game in Opener | date=2000-10-21 | publisher=NY Daily News | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2000/10/21/2000-10-21_on_computer__yankees_more_th.html | accessdate=2008-06-25 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * In 2004, [[Minnesota Twins]] [[catcher]] [[Joe Mauer]] had surgery for kidney stones. A stent was used to allow two stones to successfully pass.<ref>{{cite web | author=Staff | date=2004-10-16 | url=http://www.rototimes.com/mlb/player/4390/notes/2004 | title=Joe Mauer | publisher=RotoTimes | accessdate=2008-05-30 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071222084420/http://www.rototimes.com/mlb/player/4390/notes/2004 | archivedate=2007-12-22 | df= }} </ref><ref>{{cite web |first = Mark |last = Sheldon |date = 2004-08-19 |url = http://yankees.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20040819&content_id=832605&vkey=news_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min |title = Notes: Hard knocks for Mauer |publisher = MLB Advanced Media L.P. |accessdate = 2008-05-30 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Chicago White Sox]] manager [[Ozzie Guillén]] was hospitalized while passing a kidney stone in 2004. He said, "that was something I don't wish anybody has, even my worst enemy."<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2004-08-18 | title=Guillen returns to ballpark after passing kidney stone | publisher=ESPN/Associated Press | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1862515 | accessdate=2008-06-22 }}</ref> * [[Rich Aurilia]], an [[infielder]] for the [[San Francisco Giants]], was rushed to a hospital in 2008 because of a kidney stone. He said, "it felt like somebody stuck a knife in my rib cage".<ref>{{cite news | last=Haft | first=Chris | date=2008-05-30 | title=Aurilia waiting on kidney stone | publisher=Major League Baseball | url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080530&content_id=2804103&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb&partnered=rss_mlb | accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> * Other current or former baseball players who have had kidney stones include [[Mike Cameron]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Mike Cameron --> | first=Joe | last=Haggerty | date=2010-06-02 | title=Cameron to meet with specialists on Wednesday | publisher=NECN | url=http://www.necn.com/06/02/10/Cameron-to-meet-with-specialists-on-Wedn/landing_sports.html?blockID=245420&feedID=3352 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130129183708/http://www.necn.com/06/02/10/Cameron-to-meet-with-specialists-on-Wedn/landing_sports.html?blockID=245420&feedID=3352 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2013-01-29 | accessdate=2010-06-04 }} </ref> [[Derek Bell (baseball)|Derek Bell]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Derek Bell --> | author=Staff | date=1998-03-14 | title=For baseball players, other athletes, creatine monhydrate has powerful lure | url=http://www.texnews.com/1998/texsports/bell0314.html | publisher=Reporter News | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref> [[Tony Fernández]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Tony Fernández --> | first=George | last=Vecsey | date=1993-09-03 | title=Sports of The Times; Fernandez Finds Life After Mets | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CEEDD113CF935A1575AC0A965958260 | website=The New York Times | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref> [[Bobby Jenks]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Bobby Jenks --> | first=Bruce | last=Levine | date=August 6, 2009 | title=Jenks out because of kidney stones | publisher=ESPN | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/chicago/news/story?id=4379956 | accessdate=2010-06-04 }}</ref> [[Whitey Kurowski]],<ref>{{cite book <!-- Whitey Kurowski --> | first=Danny | last=Litwhiler |author2=Sargent, James E. |author3=Musial, Stan |author4= Sargent, Jim | title=Danny Litwhiler: Living the Baseball Dream | year=2007 | publisher=Temple University Press | isbn=1-59213-524-2 }}</ref> [[Bill Mazeroski]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Bill Mazeroski --> | first=Mike | last=Dodd | date=November 13, 2010 | work=USA Today | title=Bill Mazeroski, hospitalized with kidney stones, misses unveiling of World Series telecast | url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/dailypitch/post/2010/11/illness-to-force-bill-mazeroski-to-miss-unveiling-of-world-series-telecast/1 | accessdate=2010-12-02 }}</ref> [[Tom Niedenfuer]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Tom Niedenfuer --> | author=Staff | date=1984-06-20 | title=Sports People; Comings and Goings | website=The New York Times | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9402E5DB1739F933A15755C0A962948260&sec=&spon= | accessdate=2008-06-29 }}</ref> [[Miguel Olivo]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Miguel Olivo --> | author=Staff | date=2004-07-01 | title=Mariners place Olivo on DL | publisher=CBC Sports | url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2004/07/01/olivo040701.html | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref> [[Jay Payton]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Jay Payton --> | first=Tyler | last=Kepner | date=2000-04-23 | title=Baseball: Mets Notebook; Reed's Left Hand Still Hurts, and He May Miss Next Start | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E03E0DF1430F930A15757C0A9669C8B63 | website=The New York Times | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref> [[Brian Roberts (baseball)|Brian Roberts]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Brian Roberts --> | last=Cariq | first=Marc | date=2008-02-22 | title=Pain Free After Two Days, Roberts Expects to Return | website=The Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/21/AR2008022102925.html | accessdate=2008-06-29 }}</ref> [[Tim Salmon]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Tim Salmon --> | author=Staff | date=2003-07-07 | title=American League: Roundup; Lima Impressive Again As Royals Beat Tigers | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9806E4D6123DF934A35754C0A9659C8B63 | website=The New York Times | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref> [[Joe Saunders]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- Joe Saunders --> | first=Mike | last=DiGiovanna | date=September 25, 2008 | title=Saunders finally passes | work=Los Angeles Times | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/sep/25/sports/sp-angelsfyi25 | accessdate=2010-06-04 }}</ref> [[James Shields (baseball)|James Shields]],<ref>{{cite news <!-- James Shields --> | first=Dick | last=Kaegel | date=October 21, 2014 | title=Kidney stone no longer an issue for Shields | work=MLB.com | url=http://m.mlb.com/news/article/99170796/kidney-stone-no-longer-an-issue-for-james-shields | accessdate=2016-03-02 }}</ref> [[Josh Willingham]]<ref>{{cite news <!-- Josh Willingham --> | first=Rob | last=Maadi | date=2007-08-09 | title=Marlins Beat Phils, Avoid Sweep | website=The Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/09/AR2007080902327.html | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref> and [[Robin Yount]].<ref>{{cite news <!-- Robin Yount --> | author=Staff | date=1991-07-16 | title=Sports People: Baseball; Brewers Place Yount On the Disabled List | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE4DA163EF935A25754C0A967958260 | website=The New York Times | accessdate=2008-06-26 }}</ref>
==Others==
* The Soap Lady, a mysterious mummified female on exhibit at the [[Mütter Museum]], may have suffered from a kidney stone or gallstone.<ref>{{cite web |last=Colimore |first=Edward |date=2008-05-17 |url=http://www.philly.com/inquirer/local/nj/20080517_Learning_secrets_of_the__soap_lady_.html |title=Learning secrets of the 'soap lady' |website=The Philadelphia Inquirer |accessdate=2008-06-27 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518104241/http://www.philly.com/inquirer/local/nj/20080517_Learning_secrets_of_the__soap_lady_.html |archivedate=2008-05-18 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Mes-jan-de-doot.JPG|right|thumb|This illustration displays the stone that Jan de Doot claims he removed from his own bladder.]]
* Dutch blacksmith [[Jan de Doot]] is remembered for having his portrait painted with the "four ounce palpable stone" that he supposedly removed from his [[perineum]] using a kitchen knife in 1651.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Murphy LJ |title=Self-performed operations for stone in the bladder |journal=British Journal of Urology |volume=41 |issue=5 |pages=515–29 |date=October 1969 |pmid=4910883 |doi=10.1111/j.1464-410X.1969.tb09956.x}}</ref> * In 1981, [[A. Bartlett Giamatti|Bart Giamatti]], the President of [[Yale University]] and future [[Commissioner of Baseball]], had a kidney stone removed.<ref>{{cite book | first=Robert P. | last=Moncreiff | year=2007 | title=Bart Giamatti: A Profile | publisher=Yale University Press | isbn=0-300-12187-3 }}</ref>
* Socialite [[Lydia Hearst-Shaw]], granddaughter of [[William Randolph Hearst]], suffers from kidney stones.<ref>{{cite news | first1=Katie | last1=Goldsmith | date=July 7, 2009 | publisher=New York Media LLC. | title=Lydia Hearst Passed a Kidney Stone This Weekend | work=New York Magazine | url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2009/07/lydia_hearst_passed_a_kidney_s.html | accessdate=2016-07-13 }}</ref>
* The CIA believes that [[terrorism|terrorist]] [[Osama bin Laden]] may have had kidney stones, an enlarged heart, low blood pressure and two missing toes.<ref>{{cite news | last=Windrem | first=Robert | date=2006-08-03 | title=How the CIA diagnoses world leaders from afar | publisher=NBC News | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14173327/ | accessdate=2006-05-24 }}</ref>
* Between 2001 and 2006, 14 American [[astronaut]]s developed kidney stones during [[space mission]]s.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | date=2006-06-27 | title=Study Examines Kidney Stone Prevention In Astronauts | publisher=Science Daily | url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2006/06/060627234104.htm | accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> During long-duration space flights, astronauts are at higher risk for kidney stones because of an increase in the amount of [[calcium]] in their blood. This is caused by a loss of bone density in [[zero gravity]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ciftçioglu N, Haddad RS, Golden DC, Morrison DR, McKay DS |title=A potential cause for kidney stone formation during space flights: enhanced growth of nanobacteria in microgravity |journal=Kidney International |volume=67 |issue=2 |pages=483–91 |date=February 2005 |pmid=15673296 |doi=10.1111/j.1523-1755.2005.67105.x}}</ref>
* In January 2014, [[Jeff Bezos]], the founder and CEO of Amazon.com suffered a kidney stone.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Elwyn | last1=Lopez | title=Jeff Bezos evacuated off Galapagos Islands for kidney stones | publisher=CNN | date=January 4, 2014 | accessdate=2016-07-13 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/04/world/jeff-bezos-evacuated-galapagos }}</ref>
* In September 2017, [[Linux]] creator [[Linus Torvalds]] passed a kidney stone over an interval he described as "seven hours of pure agony".<ref>{{cite web | first1=Simon | last1=Sharwood | date=September 4, 2017 | work=The Register | title=Linus Torvalds passed a kidney stone and then squeezed out Linux 4.13 | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/09/04/linux_4_13_released/ | accessdate=2017-09-05 | postscript=. }}</ref>
===Fictional=== Fictional incidents of kidney stones have been portrayed in the media on several occasions.
* In season one, episode 11 of ''[[Modern Family (TV series)|Modern Family]]'', [[Phil Dunphy]] ([[Ty Burrell]]) is seen writhing on the bed because of a kidney stone, and Claire has to drive him to the hospital.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Robert | last1=Canning | date=January 7, 2010 | title=Modern Family: "Up All Night" Review | website=IGN | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2010/01/07/modern-family-up-all-night-review | accessdate=2015-07-09 | publisher=Ziff-Davis }}</ref>
* In season five, episode 11 of "Reba" entitled "Brock's Got Stones", Brock Hart has Kidney Stones, and passes them on his own.<ref>{{cite web | title=Season 5, Episode 11 Brock's Got Stones | publisher=TV Guide | date=January 13, 2006 | url=https://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/reba/episode-11-season-5/brocks-got-stones/100369/ | accessdate=2018-12-01 }}</ref>
* In season two, episodes 15–16 of ''[[Deadwood (TV series)|Deadwood]]'', [[Al Swearengen]] ([[Ian McShane]]) suffers from kidney stones. These are painfully treated by Doc Cochran ([[Brad Dourif]]) using a makeshift device.<ref>{{cite book | first=David | last=Lavery | year=2006 | title=Reading Deadwood: A Western to Swear by | publisher=I.B.Tauris | isbn=1-84511-221-0 }}</ref>
* During the 100th episode of the [[situational comedy]] ''[[Friends]]'', [[Joey Tribbiani]] ([[Matt LeBlanc]]) suffers back pains and later passes kidney stones.<ref>"[[List of Friends episodes|The One with the Triplets]]". [[Friends]]. October 8. No. 100, season 5.</ref> * On an episode of ''[[Seinfeld]]'', [[Cosmo Kramer]] ([[Michael Richards]]) suffers from a kidney stone. He eventually passes the stone at a carnival, but the pain induced by its passing causes him to scream so loudly that he interrupts the carnival and causes a tightrope walker to fall.<ref>"[[The Gymnast]]". [[Seinfeld]]. 1994-11-03. No. 6, season 6.</ref> * In an episode of the TV comedy ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'', [[Maxwell Klinger]] suffers through and passes a kidney stone.<ref>"[[M*A*S*H (season 10)|Follies of the Living – Concerns of the Dead]]". [[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]. January 4, 1982. No 10, season 10.</ref>
